xocs:funding.xocs:funding-agency-matched-string: Office of the Royal Development Projects Board

xocs:funding-list.xocs:funding-text: This project was partly funded through grants received from the Office of the Royal Development Projects Board (RDPB), while most of the financial support was obtained from The Thailand Research Fund, The TRF Senior Research Scholar RTA 5880002 (2015–2018) to SP. We thank the members of the Animal Systematics Research Unit for their invaluable assistance in the field. Last but not least, we extend our deep gratitude to Nathalie Yonow (U.K.) for polishing the English of the manuscript.

organization.$: Institute for Problems of Ecology and Evolution

head.citation-title: A new species of trichopeltis pocock, 1894 from southern china, with a checklist and a distribution map of trichopeltis species (diplopoda, polydesmida, cryptodesmidae)
head.abstracts: © Natdanai Likhitrakarn et al.The millipede genus Trichopeltis Pocock, 1894 contains 12 described species including a new species from southern China described here. Trichopeltis sutchariti sp. n. can be distinguished from congeners by its gonopods that are strongly caudolaterally curved and have a prominent, high, curved, densely setose process on each coxa. An updated checklist and a distribution map are provided for all species of the genus.

grant-text.$: This project was partly funded through grants received from the Office of the Royal Development Projects Board (RDPB), while most of the financial support was obtained from The Thailand Research Fund, The TRF Senior Research Scholar RTA 5880002 (2015-2018) to SP. We thank the members of the Animal Systematics Research Unit for their invaluable assistance in the field. Last but not least, we extend our deep gratitude to Nathalie Yonow (U.K.) for polishing the English of the manuscript.

Trichopeltis sutchariti sp. n. can be distinguished from congeners by its gonopods that are strongly caudolaterally curved and have a prominent, high, curved, densely setose process on each coxa. An updated checklist and a distribution map are provided for all species of the genus.
